TopicTitle: [Updated September 27th] A Planet Divided: The Story of the Kold War

Articles.Content:
When will there be any more on this? I love it!

Thanks for the kind words! I've been working on the next chapter, but it's taking a while. Fortunately for you guys (but unfortunately for me), it's going to be even longer than the last one; I want to wrap up Chapter 3 with the next three updates. Don't worry, this story's still got a long ways to go!
thank you! It's an amazing story, and I have used some of its history in my series, if that's alright.

Hi everyone! It certainly has been a while, hasn't it? Well do not worry, brave readers, as the latest chapter is very close!

It's not quite ready yet, sorry. SoonTM!

Part of the reason that it's been taking so long is that I've been very busy in real life, as well as this is the longest segment yet in the story. Its the equivalent of three missions, and is currently registering over 6300 words and takes up 18 pages, all before adding pictures. It's going to be a long one, guys.

As for the bigger picture, the story is finally nearing the end of Chapter 3. After this segment is published, there's only one episode to go before Chapter 3's explosive finale! The kerbals will be on their way to the Mun at last!

Suggestions and feedback are most welcome, so feel free to post your thoughts of the story so far, as well as the new episode when it drops!

As for the future of Kold War, you'll just have to wait and see, but I can tell you that the story will definitely not stop at the Mun. Of course, we actually have to get to the Mun first, which won't happen until Chapter 6, if my outline holds.

In short, there's still a lot of Kold War to come, KSP 1.0 might come out before I post the final chapter!

Hit a small snag while taking pictures; the new chapter is nearly here!

At last! 7200 words later, the latest chapter is complete! Enjoy!

USKK

Six Months Later

UNN News Van

Erdan Kerman, the finest newscaster in the USKK (at least in his studio's mind, but that's really all that matters), eyed a small, unkempt house.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Are you sure this is the right place?Ã¢â‚¬Å“ his camerakerbal, who was doubling as his driver, asked.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is it,Ã¢â‚¬Å“ Erdan looked at the piece of paper upon which the address of that tiny abode was scrawled. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Get the gear, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re going in."

Ã¢â‚¬Å“First of all, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d like to thank you for this interview, Desdin.Ã¢â‚¬Å“ Erdan said, as he settled into the chair heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d been provided. Most of his interviews were conducted in the comfort of ErdanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s own studio, but Desdin Kerman had insisted on holding this one in his personal home. By the looks of the drawn blinds, clutter, and general dustiness, the former kerbonaut didn't look like he got many visitors. Ã¢â‚¬Å“With the upcoming launch of Uranus X, it will be excellent to get your perspective on the space program. Not many kerbals have seen the inside of the program like yourself!Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes,Ã¢â‚¬Å“ Desdin replied, staring downwards at his hands. Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s finally time to get this off my chest.Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Erdan pressed on. Ã¢â‚¬Å“You've certainly been through a lot in the past few months, haven't you? What with being selected as one of the USKK's newest kerbonauts, launching on the ill-fated Uranus VIII mission, and that daring feat of courage you pulled off! I guess my first question is, why aren't you still with the space program?Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Desdin laughed ruefully, a faraway look in his eyes. Erdan was not exactly sure how to respond, so he took advantage of this awkward moment to make sure the camerakerbal had the two framed correctly. Eventually, Desdin did speak.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬ËœFeat of courageÃ¢â‚¬â„¢. Really? Is that what they're calling it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Now Erdan was doubly confused. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Are you implying that actual events went differently?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm sure you are aware of the space programÃ¢â‚¬â„¢sÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ Ã¢â‚¬ËœkerbalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ policy.Ã¢â‚¬Â Desdin positively spat the word.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Policy? ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just a word the public uses to describe missions which undergo minor mishaps. I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t see howÃ¢â‚¬â€Ã¢â‚¬Â

Still avoiding direct eye contact, Desdin cut him off. Ã¢â‚¬Å“It may not be official, but what if I told you that the failures are deliberately encouraged, just to make missions more exciting?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d have to say IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d have trouble believing you. Does this really happen in the program?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, Mr. Erdon, it doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t just happen, but is encouraged by the highest levels of the program themselves.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Erdan,Ã¢â‚¬Â the reporter corrected, Ã¢â‚¬Å“and really? Jebediah himself signed off on deliberately sabotaging the missions?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sabotage? Oh no. The rockets are never deliberately tampered with, but checks for mistakes made during construction are lacklustre, leading to the errors weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re accustomed to seeing during the missions.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Erdan sat back. This certainly didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t sound like the space program heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d been reporting on for the past couple of years. He was tempted to dismiss DesdinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s claims as mere fear mongering. But could the kerbal really be telling the truth? He was a former kerbonaut after all. Besides, this sounded like the beginnings of a fantastic story.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Okay,Ã¢â‚¬Â he said. Ã¢â‚¬Å“So how does this Ã¢â‚¬ËœpolicyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ work? Is this connected to your departure from the space program?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“In time, Erdin, in time. First, let me share with you its very beginning. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sure youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re familiar with Uranus III...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Five months ago

Uranus III, 400 km above Kerbin

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Approaching MECO, all systems nominal.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that Control, shutting down engine.Ã¢â‚¬Â Donnand Kerman spoke, as he pressed a button on the lower left side of his control panel.

Uranus IIIÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s orbital operations motor slowly throttled down, leaving the spacecraft in a comfortable medium Kerbin orbit. While certainly not approaching the height the CKFN had achieved with their unkerballed Caelus I, it still was impressive. You could definitely see a lot more of Kerbin from up here.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oooh, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re passing over the USKK! Let me get the camera out!Ã¢â‚¬Â Rondred's voice floated up from below Don. The Uranus program had improved upon its first iteration, and now both kerbals were pointed Ã¢â‚¬ËœupÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, to avoid injuries like poor Jorfred. Uranus II had been the first flight to fly with the updated design, and based on feedback from that mission, the engineers had placed a hole in between the capsules to allow the pilots to talk to each other without requiring an intercom.

Another new feature of this mission was a television camera, which Ron was currently trying to focus on Kerbin. The news stations back on the ground wanted live footage from orbit, so they lobbied to get a camera onto the spacecraft. The space program, eager to increase its public image in the wake of the Uranus I incident, happily complied.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, get some shots of me too!Ã¢â‚¬Â Don called down to the other kerbal, though he didn't really mind if all the footage taken during the flight were just of Kerbin. The kerbals back on the ground absolutely loved getting shots of the planet, and being this far up, one could very easily see the curvature of the planet. It was just so prettyÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

The harsh crackle of the radio awoke Don from his reverie. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uranus III, this is Mission Control. Do you copy?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that, Control. What are things looking like from down there, Gene?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Just fine, Don. All systems are looking nominal. Speaking of which, it's time to activate the reason you're up there. Prepare to deploy the solar panels!Ã¢â‚¬Â

This was the moment Donnand had been waiting for. Previous missions had been limited by the amount of power they could carry into orbit, bringing them back too quickly to do extended scientific studies or detailed analyses of how the spacecraft responded to being in orbit. These new solar panels would mean that the life support and heaters could stay on for longer, extending their time in space to many hours, and theoretically many days. Though Don would prefer to perhaps get a larger capsule, if they were planning to stay up here for that long.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Stow the camera, Ron. It's time for the big show!Ã¢â‚¬Â The other kerbal knew just as well how big of a moment this was, and forgot to put away the camera in his excitement, leaving it floating around the capsule, still broadcasting. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yep, the panels are ready to go!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Control, keep an eye on those power readings, we are ready to deploy the panels.Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that, you are clear to begin.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You hear that, Ron? Activate!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ron pushed the deployment button (which sadly was neither Big nor Red), and Don watched the readings. Ten seconds went by, then thirty, and then a full minute, while the battery banks were still showing the same passive draw in energy that was characteristic of the default power setup of Uranus. After two minutes had passed, Don radioed Control.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Gene, I'm not seeing an increase in power. Are you guys receiving any data?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Strange, we registered the Ã¢â‚¬Ëœdeploy panelsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ command, but the batteries aren't charging. Can you get visual confirmation?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Don peeked out the window, and spotted nothing but stars.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's a negative, Control. The panels are not deployed. Repeat, we have a negative on that deployment.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Okay. This is a problem. You only have enough power for one more orbit at that altitude; we'll have to bring you back down soon if we donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get those panels fixed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Before Don could reply, he noticed a screw floating past his face. Maneuvering in the tight confines of his capsule, he looked downward. Rondred had disassembled his control panel, and was busily inspecting various bits of wiring.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh, roger that Control, let me just...ah...get back to you in a second,Ã¢â‚¬Å“ he said, turning off the radio. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ron, uhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦what are you doing?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm trying to fix these blasted panels! There's got to be a reason they won't deploy!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Correct me if I'm wrong, but I thought Danbro wouldn't even let you look at that panel when you visited the VAB last week.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, I've been looking at it for the last two hours, and nothing bad has happened!Ã¢â‚¬Â The navball came loose, and began orbiting Ron like a small moon. Don made a mental note to pocket it at some point. Ron continued.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Besides, what's the worst that can happen? You've got all the controls in your pod, and Ground Control has access to all the data on this panel anyways.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah well, you've already taken it apart. What's your plan to fix these panels?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I was thinking that maybe a wire came loose or something, but the button feeds into the computer just fineÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ Hm, do you think it's a computer problem?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Why?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, where else could it be located?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I don't know, Don. ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a lot of wire between the computer and the panels, the panels could have got stuck, or maybe the motors are burnt out? There's a bunch of places where something could go wrong!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“But there are two solar panels, and it's gotta be said, the chances of them both failing in the exact same way are pretty low.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm. You know what, there are two copies of allcomponents after the computer, from motors to wiring. Unless the engineers somehow installed two defective panels, the computer has to be it!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Can you debug the thing?Ã¢â‚¬Â Ron looked at his controls. Ã¢â‚¬Å“My panel is notÃ¢â‚¬Â¦uhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦set up for that right now.Ã¢â‚¬Â Indeed, the console now looked like some sort of wild animal had taken large bites out of it.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sure, just don't break anything--,Ã¢â‚¬Â Don replied, watching the throttle control float past him. Ã¢â‚¬Å“--else.Ã¢â‚¬Â

He quickly brought up the debug commands by pressing a pair of keys simultaneously on the top and bottom on his panel, and looked for anything strange in the output. He found it immediately.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey Ron, it looks like we've got a bunch of Null Reference Exceptions. They're filling the output log, and stopping the computer from responding to the solar panel subroutine!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Log? Subroutine? Dammit Don, I'm a kerbonaut, not a computer scientist!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Basically, the computer's clogged up because it's receiving a lot of errors from another system, so it can't execute our command to deploy the solar panels.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I knew it wasn't the panels!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, how to do thisÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ Hm, it looks like our atmospheric trajectory computation module is outputting the errors. I think it has something to do with the atmospheric sensors reading zero, but it's trying to calculate our trajectory anyway. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going to try and rewire the system, but it could take a while.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Donnand was no technical whiz, but after his and RonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s misadventure in Mission Control a year ago, he had been more interested in the technical aspects of the capsules. He was able to navigate the system without too much difficulty, and found the trajectories module, a small black box sitting underneath his control panel.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ron, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve found the module! Can you pass me the needle nose pliers? I should be able to rewire it from here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

At this moment, the lights in the capsule flickered, punctuated by a yell from below.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ron? Are you alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“UghÃ¢â‚¬Â¦yep, just touched a couple of wires I shouldn't have.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“What the--! Our power levels just dropped three hundred percent! Romfarer's eye, what happened?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I er, may have shorted one of the batteriesÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ Well, former battery; it's more of a battery-shaped piece of plastic now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“We donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t even have enough power to deorbit ourselves now; we need to get those panels fixed fast! Tell you what, I'll just take the module out entirely. It'll mean we're a few kilometres off with our landing, but that's no problem. We'd better hope that the panels aren't damagedÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Don gritted his teeth and cut the wires from the trajectories box leading into the main flight computer. Suddenly, a couple of red lights on his console turned green, signifying the computer was no longer overloaded. DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s worried face broke into a wide grin. It worked!

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Okay Ron, press the button, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re running out of power fast here!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Here goes!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Two simultaneous clunk-whirrs reverberated through the hull, and a few seconds later, the power levels began rapidly rising.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes! We did it! Power's back online!Ã¢â‚¬Â

The two kerbals shared a zero-gravity high-four through the small hole between the capsules.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“You didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have to recap the entire mission.Ã¢â‚¬Â Erdan told Desdin. Ã¢â‚¬Å“I did report on it after all.Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Ã¢â‚¬Å“So you know how popular the footage from RondredÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s camera feed was with audiences back on Kerbin.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Of course,Ã¢â‚¬Â Erdan replied. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Audiences love that sort of dramatic tension. Two kerbals stranded in a dying spacecraft with time running out. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s like a movie! The fact that it was actually happening in real time only heightened the drama.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“So you understand why the space program wouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t be opposed to having that sort of thing happen more often.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“So youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re saying they just cut out safety entirely?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, not quite. But it became common practice to skip final checks, and cut corners during manufacturing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Wait a minute. WasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t that new engineer Jebediah brought into the program supposed to fix those problems? Are you saying that this didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t happen?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Are you kidding? If anything the rockets are getting worse now that Doodbro is part of the program. Having another manager didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t fix anything, it just kept the program mired in bureaucracy and red tape. Different departments donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t talk to

each other, parts donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t work together, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s chaos.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Erdan didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know what to say.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Of course,Ã¢â‚¬Â Desdin continued. Ã¢â‚¬Å“This all came to a head during Uranus V.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Three months later

Uranus V, Low Kerbin Orbit

Uranus V floated in the dark. Its pilot, Sean Kerman, lay back and let out a sigh of relief. The rocket booster had just decoupled, and he was safely in orbit. Despite intensive training, nothing could have prepared himself for the ferocity of a rocket launch. He looked out the window nervously. Not only was he the only kerbal on this mission, this was his very first time in space. He couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get over how big everything was, as well as that instant death lay literally seventeen millimetres away.

To avoid dwelling on such unpleasant images, he turned his thoughts towards the mission. As a former reactor technician, he was the most qualified of all USKK kerbonauts for the task at hand. Wernher Von Kerman's prototype Radioisotope Thermal Generator was supposed to provide a steady trickle of power through harnessing the heat a sample of radioactive material gave off. Naturally, the technology had been thoroughly tested on the ground, but this was its first demonstration test in orbit.

Sean was merely there to monitor the RTG and make sure nothing went wrong. So simple, even a probe could do it! He suspected that the only reason he was along for the ride was to boost the prestige of the space program, in ways an unkerballed spacecraft could not.

Click

Click

The radiation counter mounted above his head made a bit of noise, then was silent. While there was more radiation up here than on the ground, the shielding of the capsule eliminated most of the nastier particles. Some still got through, but Sean had seen much worse.

The radio crackled. Ã¢â‚¬Å“HowÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the RTG looking, Sean?Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Current is nominal, Control. All systems are green.Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that. Wernher will be happy.Ã¢â‚¬Å“ The ground controller stopped talking, but failed to sign off, presumably speaking to other members of Mission Control in the background. Sean waited for him to continue. Ã¢â‚¬Å“The ballistics guys want you to

fire your engine for a few seconds at periapsis; this will adjust your orbit to pass through KerbinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s radiation belts. They want to get a reading of the number of ionizing particles you can pick up, for a better idea of how the capsule shielding is holding up.Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that Control, let me know when and where to burn.Ã¢â‚¬Â As he turned off the radio, Sean grumbled to himself, Ã¢â‚¬Å“For NovaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sake, I am just a probe.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Still, it was a damn sight better than being stuck in an office down on Kerbin, the view was fantastic up here.

As the time came to make the burn, Sean gripped the controls, and began to turn the spacecraft, hearing the gentle thrummmmof the reaction wheels spinning up. Just like the simulations, he thought to himself.

Click click click

The counter started making more noise. Sean looked up in confusion. He hadnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t even made the burn; thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s no way he could be in the radiation belts yet. Perhaps this was simply a more energetic region of space? He put the counterÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s increased activity out of his mind.

He gingerly throttled up the main engine, feeling the ship vibrate around him, and the gentle roar of propellant leaving the spacecraft. The burn went off without a hitch, and he shut down the engine.

ClickclickcliCkClickClickclickcLIckclickClicKclickclickclick

With the roar of the engine gone, the radiation counterÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s frantic complaining could be plainly heard. Eyes wide, Sean looked around the capsule in panic. The counter was registering more and more radiation by the second, and he had no idea what was causing it.

This hazard was accompanied by another, more insidious problem. The lights in the capsule began to flicker, signifying a drop in power generation.

In a flash, Sean realized the cause of these problems: the RTG. He quickly radioed the ground.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Control, I have an emergency here. The RTG is leaking material, repeat, the RTG is breached. Please advise.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that Sean, weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re reading a power decrease in your ship, as well as increased radiation levels. Hang on, I need to advise with the Power team.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A yellow light began pulsing, signifying a Ã¢â‚¬ËœHigh RadiationÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ alert.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Control, I know what the problems are! IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m asking you, what should I do?Ã¢â‚¬Â

No response. Fuming, Sean thanked Nova that heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d trained well for this mission, then slid out a tray which contained a red button marked Ã¢â‚¬ËœAbortÃ¢â‚¬â„¢. Slamming his fist down on the button produced a small jolt which ran through the spacecraft.

Clickclickclick click click...click....click...............click...

Sean sighed in relief as the RTG floated away from him, its linkages to the spacecraft severed. Then his radio crackled again.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, Control?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uranus V, this is Gene. We want you to...wait. WhatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s your status? Our radiation sensors are back to normal.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Affirmative, Gene. I jettisoned the RTG module.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“What? V, that means weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve now got a piece of radioactive space debris floating around! Why did you do that?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“I stand by my actions; the radiation would have reached critical levels in less than a minute had I not decoupled the module.Ã¢â‚¬Â

For a long moment, Gene did not reply. Then he sighed heavily. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Fine. Well, we got some good data, so begin your deorbit burn and return home.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Roger that Control.Ã¢â‚¬Â Sean said stiffly.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“And Sean? IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m glad youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re alright.Ã¢â‚¬Â

The kerbonautÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s icy mood abated somewhat. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks, Gene.Ã¢â‚¬Â At least one member of Mission Control cared.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“That damaged RTG is still floating around Kerbin,Ã¢â‚¬Å“ Desdin explained. Ã¢â‚¬Å“It was later found that the vibrations from launch had shook apart the containment unit, and allowed the radioactive material to escape. SeanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s maneuvers had The RTG was then considered too dangerous for rocketry, and shelved for the time being.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Erdan paused before responding. Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not sure how this mission relates. Sure, audiences enjoyed SeanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s reactions, but the entire incident was over in less than two minutes. Most kerbals missed it entirely.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not why I told you about it. My point was that Mission Control was increasingly distant and unconcerned by the kerbalsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ sacrifices and problems.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“From what you told me about the lax safety standards, I imagine the increased number of incidents would wear on them after a while.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Exactly, Erdin. Eventually, the little problems became part of the mission, just like any old maneuver or systems check. Because itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not as if any error ever caused a mission failure now, did it?Ã¢â‚¬ÂAside from the mispronunciation of his name

(which he was starting to think was intentional by now), Erdan noticed that DesdinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s right hand clenched into a fist as he spoke this last sentence.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“But one did, didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t it?Ã¢â‚¬Â he said carefully, knowing this would be a sensitive area for the former kerbonaut. Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uranus VIII.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Desdin said nothing. Erdan wondered if heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d pushed the kerbal too far. In fact, the entire reason heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d decided to do this interview was in order to get more details about that mysterious mission.

After a full two minutes, Desdin finally looked into ErdanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s eyes for the first time. Despite himself, the reporter shivered. Those eyes were like cold steel, hard and intense.
